text:
500,000 $. That's what the promising SpinLaunch startup aims to spend for launching a satellite on a sub-orbital flight. The American private startup which received the help of the American NASA agency owns a patent that allows to launch satellite in a very eco-friendly particular way. How does it work ? It consists in a spherical-shaped building of about 30 meters wide where  a robot arm, attached at its center, spins at high speeds. A satellite that weights about 30 kg is attached at the end of the arm. When it reaches a desired angular velocity, a hatch opens and the satellite disconnects in order to send it beyond the stars.
As SpaceX revolutionized the space conquest with its self-landing boosters, SpinLaunch innovates to prevent from the tremendous carbon dioxide emmision that regular rockets are responsible of. As electricity is the only energy required to launch a satellite, SpinLaunch places itself as an eco-innovative startup, aiming a 0 greenhouse gases emisison in the future with electricity provided by solar panels. SpinLaunch  plans on 4 to 5 launches a day with a cost at around 500,000 $. Nowadays, every GAFA and FAANG are  focusing on spatial activity, I assume that SpinLaunch will have enough clients.
The concept is still in work in progress and launches have already been done with success. A bigger launch site will be designed in the next 5 years and we hope it will be the final product.
Eco-innovative projects are getting more and more trendy but SpinLaunch is the one I have faith on. As it received the help of NASA, it means that it’s a company we can have trust on. A cheap, silent, carbon-free way of sending satellites can appear utopic at first but as more we dig in, it feels achievable. Moreover, the startup is putting a lot of interest on their communication that leads to multiple explanation of their concept and all the technical issues they went through. As an example, the arm has to be surrounded by void to avoid any air friction. It means that the building is the second biggest piece of void in the world. How do you achieve that ? By reuniting the greatest engineers in the world. As a future engineer, I found the project really exciting and I am looking forward to hear from the advancement soon
